newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya bourse regulator in agreement with Malaysia.
newsitem.headline: Kenya bourse regulator in agreement with Malaysia.

text.p: The chief executives of Kenyan and Malaysian capital markets signed a bilateral agreement on Monday aimed at improving the efficiency of the Nairobi bourse -- Africa's fifth largest.
The agreement was signed by the head of the Capital Markets Authority of Kenya (CMA), Paul Melly, and the chairman of the Securities Commission of Malaysia, Mohd Munir Abdul Majid.
Majid said increased globalisation of securities markets had created challenges for domestic enforcement agencies.
"Countries in the south must not only have the desire, but also the resolve and shall I say, the political will to share whatever knowledge and technical assistance that can be offered," Majid said.

His views were supported by Melly who added: "Kenya stands to benefit from drawing on the experience of Malaysia on various issues relating to capital markets development -- especially in nurturing the emergence of new market institutions and new products."
Melly added that the Rating Agency of Malaysia would also act as a role model for the establishment of a similar institution in Kenya.
The agreement will facilitate the exchange of information on how to establish the minimum standards required for an efficient market.
The agreement will also pave way for Malaysian technical assistance and training of Kenyans at the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange in Malaysia.
Majid also said this was the first time Malaysia had signed such an understanding with an African securities regulator.
The Nairobi bourse has a market capitalisation of $2.28 billion and is ranked the fifth in Africa.
